title: Is the argument that 'beliefs should be deemed true until proven otherwise' in philosophy justified or valid? - Quora

response.answer_text: This sounds like a garbled version of the principle of credulity, a principle advocated by Richard Swinburne: ‘How things seem to be is good grounds for a belief about how things are.’ (I believe that the principle was first proposed by C.D. Broad, but Swinburne is now its best known defender). Swinburne argued that without this principle we would not be able to form many beliefs about the world, and so would be unable to function. Right now, I see what looks like a computer screen in front of me. I don’t stop to develop a watertight argument to show that it is a computer screen, I just assume that it is a computer screen until I acquire good reason to think it isn’t. What’s the difference between the Principle of Credulity and “beliefs should be deemed true until proven otherwise”? I can’t really see any difference in meaning between “I believe that P” and “I deem it to be true that P.” My beliefs just are the things I deem to be true. But there is a difference between it seeming to be that there is a computer in front of me, and my believing that there is a computer in front of me, such that the former can be grounds for the latter. (I can not believe that things are as they seem, but I cannot deem that things are not as I believe them to be). (If there’s some difference in meaning between “I deem it true that” and “I believe that” it needs to be explained). Accepting the Principle of Credulity would perhaps mean accepting the point that the onus is on the person who thinks I’m wrong to prove that. As it happens, I am not convinced by the Principle of Credulity. Swinburne argues for the Principle of Credulity based on the fact that Without This We Couldn’t Function. He thinks we should accept epistemic principles if those epistemic principles are necessary for us to function. I think we could apply the Without This We Couldn’t Function principle directly to perceptions. If I gave up the belief that there is a computer in front of me right now, I couldn’t function. But suppose it seems to me that I see an angel. I could function perfectly well while believing “I am seeing a hallucination not a real angel.” The Principle of Credulity would lead me to believe in the Angel, but the Without This We Couldn’t Function Principle would not. (When I put that point to Swinburne, he did admit that there is a distinction between things that seem to be so, and things such that if I didn’t have them, I would be unable to function.) If you want to know more about the topic, you might want to look up more about the Principle of Credulity.

Should beliefs be deemed true until proven otherwise? Obviously no. Should beliefs be deemed false until proven otherwise? Still no! Don’t confuse belief with fact. We all believe things that are not proven, and many of them cannot be proven. I believe that my wife is not having an affair with another guy. Did I prove this? Do I have cameras watching her or detectives following her? No. But she has earned my trust.When I get into my car to drive to work, I believe I’ll arrive there without getting hit by a bus. Have I proven this conclusion by analyzing bus patterns or getting to know bus drivers? No, but I drive carefully and bus drivers have been pretty good too in my experience.I believe that the universe is infinite in size. Have I proven this? No, but makes the most sense to me.Many of the things we believe are like this: They are built on trust, experience, evidence, and reason — but not on proof. Also, it is implicitly understood that a belief may turn out to be wrong. Some beliefs involve some vague elements that cannot not even be clearly articulated, let alone proven. People could not function without having these sorts of beliefs, and for sane people, such beliefs usually work out well. When they don’t work out, we learn something.
